skill.name: unity-ecs-patterns
skill.description: Master Unity ECS (Entity Component System) with DOTS, Jobs, and Burst for high-performance game development. Use when building data-oriented games, optimizing performance, or working with large entity counts.
skill.summary: Master Unity ECS (Entity Component System) with DOTS, Jobs, and Burst for high-performance game deve...

security_audit.summary: The skill content is static documentation and code examples. No file access, network calls, or execution logic is present.

content.value_statement: You need practical Unity ECS guidance that scales to many entities. This skill provides clear patterns and examples for DOTS, Jobs, and Burst.
actual_capabilities: Explains ECS core concepts and data oriented vs OOP tradeoffs
Provides component and system examples with ISystem and IJobEntity
Shows entity query patterns and command buffer usage
Demonstrates aspects, singletons, and baking workflows
Includes native collection job patterns and performance tips
limitations: Does not integrate with a specific Unity project or version
Does not generate or modify project files automatically
Does not cover rendering, networking, or UI systems in depth
Does not replace profiling or performance testing

use_cases.title: Migrate OOP to ECS
use_cases.description: Map MonoBehaviour logic into ECS components, systems, and aspects.

use_cases.title: Optimize large entity counts
use_cases.description: Apply Burst, Jobs, and chunk patterns for CPU bound gameplay.

use_cases.title: Set DOTS coding standards
use_cases.description: Adopt consistent patterns for queries, ECB usage, and baking.

prompt_templates.title: ECS basics
prompt_templates.scenario: New to DOTS and ECS concepts
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain ECS entities, components, and systems with a small movement example.

prompt_templates.title: System design
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ISystem pattern for movement and health using Burst and queries.

prompt_templates.title: Structural changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to use EntityCommandBuffer for spawning and cleanup safely.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced jobs
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide an IJobEntity or IJobParallelFor example using native collections.

output_examples.input: Give me a DOTS pattern for spawning enemies with timers
output: Use an ISystem with a Spawner component and timer

best_practices: Use Burst on systems and jobs whenever possible
Batch structural changes with command buffers
anti_patterns: Using managed types inside Burst jobs
Performing structural changes inside jobs without ECB

faq.question: Which Unity versions are compatible?
faq.answer: It targets Unity DOTS and Entities packages, so check your installed package versions.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides patterns and examples, but does not edit or run your Unity project.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my existing ECS code?
faq.answer: It offers guidance you can adapt to your codebase, not automatic refactors.

faq.question: Does it access my files or data?
faq.answer: No, it only provides documentation and examples.

faq.question: What if a pattern does not compile?
faq.answer: Verify your Entities package version and API changes, then adjust namespaces and types.

faq.question: How does it compare to official docs?
faq.answer: It distills common production patterns while the official docs cover full API details.
